And how do you know that this sensation can't be explained by neurology? Neurologic explanations have the advantage that nerves can actually be observed, unlike qi.

The theory of Qi was developed at a time when dissection of the human body was punishable by death, so those developing the theory had no way to know anything about nerves. Trying to make sense of radicular and other types of referred pain without knowing about nerves, they came up with a remarkably good model. After all, nerves are laid out in something like a meridian pattern, and nerve impulses are a type of energy. They got a lot of it wrong, at least in part because they had no way to observe the physical structures inside the body that were responsible for the phenomena they were trying to explain, but they got some things right.

Instead of codifying and worshipping the flawed theory they came up with, I think we should appreciate and honor the developers of the theory for their ability to come so close to the truth with such little evidence.

It is true that western medicine has been overrun by the profit motive. As a physician, I despise that aspect of my field. However, much of the basic science underlying our understanding of the human body in health and disease was discovered before money became the bottom line, and there is still basic research being done that is not funded by drug companies. One of the hallmarks of pseudoscience, at least in the field of health care, is that it does not fit with what we know about how the body works. That is still true, even in an environment where most new "knowledge" is suspect because of the financial bias of those "discovering" it.

Are you aware that Einstein used no instruments (he collected no data) when he developed his special and general theories of relativity? As one physicist told me, relativity was the product solely of Einstein's magnificent mind.

Eddington did use a telescope to verify Einstein's notion that light is affected by gravity and atomic clocks were used to verify time dilation.

"But perhaps the problem is one of paradox, not exclusion, which is to say that while New York has become an increasingly inhospitable place to incubate a career as an artist, it has become an ever easier place to experience and consume the arts."

The mainstream museums remain very expensive and people without money can easily feel excluded.

Thus cities and communities under the consumerist and even culturalist radar like Buffalo are thriving and will continue to do so: they are nurturing art and artists of all genres, all levels, all voices. Jane Jacobs said a great, living city requires eyes on the street. She was referring to safety and security. New York is safer, but the cost has been the incubation of street style, art, fashion, words, and so on. Not a coincidence, perhaps, that "street food" is so in vogue.

I went on a very useful "study trip" to New York organized by my art school and two of my teachers.. I had my eyes opened wide to how much money dominates the New York art scene. I knew pretty quickly that I did not want to move to New York to be an artist. There is too much pressure and competition for attention from the "rich"- meaning art consumers or the critics who influence art world debate.

I do not believe that money is inherently evil, and I don't think that the answer to this problem is to try to remove capitalism from the art world. The countries that have the best "high" artists right now have gotten to that point by letting capitalist investment be the organizing principle of their art scenes. Maybe it is because I am no longer a "high" artist that I don't have much sympathy for whiny bohemians who think that somebody should give them money to express themselves- just because it's "the right thing to do."

Many of the students at my art school had no idea how they were going to actually earn a living after they got their degree, and they seemed to think that the world owed them attention for whatever they created. Graduates often said: "Going to ____ was great, but it didn't prepare me at all for what I'm doing now."

But the Big Money in art is disgusting. I remember reading about a high-flying collector who was very interested in a particular piece when he thought it was a Murakami. After he found out it wasn't he lost all interest. So it goes...

Kidding, right? Surely you've heard of Cindy Sherman, Keith Haring, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Barbara Kruger, filmmakers Jim Jarmusch and Kathryn Bigelow, musicians Debby Harry, The Ramones, the Talking Heads, actor Steve Buscemi. I could go on and on.
Sorry if none of this work "enriched YOUR life."
(And I bought a 3,000 sq ft loft in Tribeca back in the day for $30,000.)

The entire hip hop movement and the zulu nation. All the works of the mosaic man and the no wave art scene downtown. Richard Hambleton and Rammellzee? Lydia Lunch or any of the films by Susan Seidalman? The endless parade of work done at Max's Kansas City, Clayton Patterson and his Essex Street gallery? Hugo Martinez and the graffiti scene uptown? The endless lists of photographers and dance studios that used to populate the place? Real New Yorkers don't need to be reminded of the cultural wonder New York used to be but I thought I'd throw a few names out there anyways.

If only the artists and hipsters who lament the "good old days" could point to some fantastic art made during that era that enriched our lives and stood the test of time. I doubt they can, which leaves me to conclude that they're simply bitter that they didn't buy a $30,000 co-op in Chelsea when the pickings were ripe.

I think this idea that the new, expensive and glitzy NYC as roost to emerging artists may confuse the antecedent with the consequent.
Something that no first year logic student would ever do ~ Affirming the consequent or fallacy of the converse,

There is a premium attached to art made by poor "creatives" in NYC. Their work is a crystallization of abject living conditions, financial insecurity and perhaps a bit of hunger. The harder it is to live in NYC, the more valuable their work becomes. Nothing needs to change for this subset of expression to flourish.

Yes, New York continues to become a place where exposure to the arts is much easier than actually being a place where art is nurtured and created. I don't think many of us want to return to the days of addicts and hustlers, but there's certainly room enough for increased and encouraged support for the evolving creation of art in its many forms. New York has always been one of the global centers where artists of every sort could evolve, find their way, explore and express the spectrum of their talent; to lose that would be, well, unthinkable.
The generosity of Mr. Bloomberg's contributions may well be tax-advantaged, but he sets an example that most of the "brash upper class" and anyone else with millions or billions (or not) would do well to follow. Let's remember that typically Americans spend more on sports than they do on the arts, so a few million here and a few million there do add up. Why not sponsor a space or spaces where artists can work, or live, or both, and where their work is reviewed on an annual (or other) basis, and their tenure continued or not? Why not give splashy headlines and parties and put names on buildings for those who want it? The goal here is support for creation and sustainability of the arts in all forms; New York is the world-known epicenter for that (so far). We need to glorify our well-heeled friends who have the resources to provide for the creation of the arts, and appreciate their generosity in public and in quieter circles.

Let's not forget that David Byrne came to NYC with a Harvard Degree crammed in with his Luna Bars, and the rest of the Talking Heads came from RISD. Also, let's not forget, how much more AFFORDABLE that education was in those days, so we could be coming in for our creative lives from middle class backgrounds. Today the financial pressure on young kids is like a boot on the back of their neck unless their folks are extremely well off.

Ginia Bellafante argues "perhaps the problem is one of paradox, not exclusion, which is to say that while New York has become an increasingly inhospitable place to incubate a career as an artist, it has become an ever easier place to experience and consume the arts."

Experience and consume on a conveyor belt with tourists clicking at each painting with their i-phone at the MoMa or Met?

Let's leave it at ''New York is a much easier place to experience and consume.''

Are we really supposed to be reassured and grateful that part of the reason of this is the personal largess of our billionaire mayor writing a personal check? Or, the necessity for art to attract a market sufficiently large to justify keeping the museum doors open to pay for all those administrator salaries? Whatever the merits for generating tourist revenue, it doesn't sound like a great incubator for creative exploration.

Someone beat you to that idea...the NYS Dept. of Taxation.

A NYS court ruling a couple of years ago ordered that non-residents who maintain a residence suitable for year-round living in NYS shall be taxed at full Resident income taxes, which is substantially more than what a non-resident working in NY pays.

When that went into effect, the sale of those so-called 'pieds-a-terre' started increasing, with many of "the rich" moving their part-time residences to NJ, specifically, Jersey City and Hoboken, and now only paying their own state tax bill...at great savings.

Bloomberg pushed NYC into being nothing more than an amusement park for artists and others in the "culture" field, that is, those involved in "fun-employment," ignoring the much-needed tax base of commerce and industry. The results are beginning to show now, with Bloomberg attempting to close his last budget with the ineffective and impossible idea of selling $2 BILLION in, of all things, limited-use taxi medallions.

Keep demanding more taxes on the rich and the only people you will have paying taxes in NYC will be the unemployed artists and people renting kyacks on the Hudson River, the results being decimated city services and an outer borough housing stock reminiscent of the bad old days of the 1970s.
How about a tax on pieds-à-terre of the wealthy that goes to fund public schools and arts programs?
In other words, for purposes of art, New York is following all of America in becoming a "service" economy rather than a "manufacturing" economy.

and that is exactly the problem

New York is the center of the art world though. Why would one move as far away from that as possible? The whole point of what David Byrne is saying is wasn't it wonderful that for a couple of generations in the 20th century, some of the greatest art was made in the greatest city and now none of that is possible anymore. New York was wonderful because you could live three miles downtown from the Met, wealthy art collectors and galleries and the rents were as cheap as cat food.

Get out of NY. Move to Detroit, Asheville Nashville or Pittsburgh. Many have found nurturing cities for making art that are affordable and easy to live in. If you have to spend 60 hours a week to pay the rent and eat you have no time to make art. NY is a great place to live as an established selling artist. It is a terrible place to try to become one.

If this is going to be a short-term deal, and the president would be ill-advised to give up anything of consequence. House Republicans do not and cannot speak with one voice, and consequently any deal that Boehner and his negotiating team would agree to will be challenged by the most radical segment of his party. He has not negotiated in good faith so far, and we have no reason to expect that anything he agrees to would be honored by the most strident members of his caucus who are in thrall to apocalyptic visions for which no amount of reality checking seems to penetrate.

As a professional mediator, I have had the occasion to see numerous situations in which attorneys representing a party are frustrated when their clients reject what appears to be a reasonable settlement because their clients are in total disarray; family members want one thing, financial supporters want something else, and assorted kibbitzers of various stripes keep interjecting their own opinions without having any skin in the game.

Over the past 10 days, we have seen House Republicans put forth one proposal after another ranging from the impossible to the improbable, none that were germane to the issue of the pending Continuing Resolution and raising the debt ceiling. It is impossible for the president to negotiate against a moving target.

At some point Speaker Boehner must be reminded that he is a constitutional duty to put the Senate measures up to a vote, up or down, and the sooner the better.
